I have always assumed this song was about Freddie's relationship with Mary Austin.  Yes, I know he was gay, but he lived with Mary for several years, and in interviews said she was the "love of his life." She is the first person he lists in his dedications for the album "Barcelona" which he did without Queen.

This is a magnificent song and a great backstory.

comment_22:
Ski actually has a point. When Freddie revealed he was gay, of course his girlfriend would be hurt. I'd feel hurt if my girlfriend told me she was a lesbian. What would that make me?

But then, he probably told her she was gay anyway, and she probably would've accepted it anyway.

If you've ever heard this song live, you have experienced true awesomeness. If you have ever BEEN there to hear it, you are an official Queen fan. Here's what Brian said on April 1st, 2006, in San Diego, CA, during Queen Tour '06.

"Now, we can do this song in one of two ways. I can sing it to you all quietly and you can sit there quietly and listen. Or, I can play, and we can all sing it together." That's what makes this song so awesome. It's so passionate in the studio version, but in concert, everyone always sang it together, because it's so easy to learn, and so irresistible to sing along with. A definite classic that any rock fan can point out, almost comparing to BoRhap.
comment_23: Oh, also, I love how the guitar seems to be singing along in this son. If you don't understand that vague point, start listening at 3:16. There are other instances of this in the song, but that's the most noticeable one to me.

comment_28:
Beautiful song. In a way, it's a lot different from Mercury's other compositions. Unlike songs such as "March of the Black Queen" and "Lily of the Valley", which often employ eloquent but borderline-nonsensical flights of fancy, Love of My Life is just a pure confession of feelings. It's straight from the heart. 

I often listen to A Night At The Opera while doing my homework; however, with this song especially, I end up forgetting the homework entirely and spacing out, drinking in the grandeur of the music....and getting an F in Algebra the next day. XD I also invariably play this song at least four times. Swooning repeatedly over Freddie's so-beautiful-that-in-all-honesty-it's-kind-of-scary falsetto. In fact, as soon as I add this comment I'm going to pull out my MP3 player and listen to this song yet again...
